issue.title: added Singh/Chopra algorithms from local copy
issue.body:
Hi,

I've been working on liboqs in my spare time and have added an algorithm I found mentioned on the Wikipedia RLWE-KEX page (i.e. the work of Singh at https://github.com/vscrypto/ringlwe).  Would you consider it for inclusion in the main liboqs project?  I hope I did the "git" part of this correctly!

Thanks,

Simon

comment.body: What I mean is, has the paper been published in a refereed conference/journal?  Not a prerequisite for inclusion in OQS, but if it's already been vetted from that perspective then we don't have to do as much vetting ourselves.

issue.title: openssl speed invalid machine command
issue.body:
When I'm running the version from today on Debian 8, I got with "openssl speed oqskex_lwe_frodo_recommended" the output:

Doing OQS KEX LWE Frodo recommended Alice 0's for 10s: Invalid machine command

All other oqskex cipher will run.

comment.body: Can you provide some more information about the environment your running in?  Specifically exact Debian version, processor, and compiler version?  We'd need that before we can hope to diagnose the error.

issue.title: openssl speed invalid machine command
issue.body:

Doing OQS KEX LWE Frodo recommended Alice 0's for 10s: Invalid machine command

All other oqskex cipher will run.

comment.body: Of course. My system has a Debian 8.6 with gcc (Debian 4.9.2-10) 4.9.2. on x86_64.

issue.title: Signature API
issue.body:
**== NOT READY TO MERGE ==**

I wanted to start the discussion on the signature API. 

I used a structure very similar to the key exchange structure (kex.h). Could you have a look and make comments / edits (users with write access to this directory can modify this branch) on this structure?

One of the doubt I have is about `priv` and (the absence of) `priv_len`. I am not sure why `priv` has a different type `void *` than the public key in the kex; do we want the same here?

Other thing about the message and hashing: do we want to make anything explicit on that matter?

comment.body:
I was talking with Dan Bernstein at Real World Crypto, and he had some suggestions about our KEX API, some of which carry forward into the design of a signature API.

Some of his comments (my wording) were:

1. the API should not require malloc's (in other words, callers pass in byte arrays of appropriate size, rather than the callee allocating it)
2. make the API as close to Supercop / NIST as possible to make it easier for people to submit
3. having the OQS_KEX or OQS_SIGN data structure is an extra hurdle for people wanting to submit
4. avoid passing the OQS_KEX or OQS_SIGN data structures down multiple levels of the stack
5. every input should be byte strings (i.e., don't use void * for private keys)
6. don't pass a random number generator down, instead rely on a global random number generator function like random_bytes
7. don't have functions representing "families of schemes" parameterized by different values, instead have each function correspond to one scheme

My opinions:

1. okay
2. okay
3. I would like to have the OQS_KEX or OQS_SIGN data structure for a few reasons: still maintaining a generic high level API that is parameterized by the scheme, and to include metadata such as key sizes and security levels
4. okay
5. For ephemeral/passive key exchange where the private key is only used once, I think void * is okay, but for schemes with long-term keys, each scheme would have to provide an explicit serialization/deserialization that the caller has to make use of; so I think for signatures byte strings is simpler (and matches Supercop / NIST)
6. It's not clear to me how to do transforms based on determinism for KEMs if you don't pass an RNG down.  But then again it's also not clear to me how to do such transforms even if you do pass an RNG down.  Thoughts?
7. Probably would simplify the API.

I'm going to try writing a signature API and post it as a comment here shortly.  Hope to get feedback from Tancrede and Christian and anyone else who wants to chime in.

issue.title: Signature API
issue.body:
**== NOT READY TO MERGE ==**

I wanted to start the discussion on the signature API. 

I used a structure very similar to the key exchange structure (kex.h). Could you have a look and make comments / edits (users with write access to this directory can modify this branch) on this structure?

One of the doubt I have is about `priv` and (the absence of) `priv_len`. I am not sure why `priv` has a different type `void *` than the public key in the kex; do we want the same here?

Other thing about the message and hashing: do we want to make anything explicit on that matter?

issue.title: Signature API
issue.body:
**== NOT READY TO MERGE ==**

I wanted to start the discussion on the signature API. 

I used a structure very similar to the key exchange structure (kex.h). Could you have a look and make comments / edits (users with write access to this directory can modify this branch) on this structure?

One of the doubt I have is about `priv` and (the absence of) `priv_len`. I am not sure why `priv` has a different type `void *` than the public key in the kex; do we want the same here?

Other thing about the message and hashing: do we want to make anything explicit on that matter?

comment.body:
This is still different from Supercop (http://bench.cr.yp.to/call-sign.html) and NIST (http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/documents/example-files/api-notes.pdf) in several ways:

1. Supercop/NIST use the term "open" rather than "verify".
2. Our lower level algorithms (e.g., OQS_SIGN_douglas_awesome_keygen) take an RNG in.
3. The order of parameters is different.
4. We have the convention of returning 1 on success, 0 on failure; Supercop/NIST return 0 on success and negative on failure.
5. Supercop/NIST don't use sig and sig_len, instead they use sm and sm_len ("signed message"), which includes a copy of the original message.

Thoughts?

issue.title: Signature API
issue.body:
**== NOT READY TO MERGE ==**

I wanted to start the discussion on the signature API. 

I used a structure very similar to the key exchange structure (kex.h). Could you have a look and make comments / edits (users with write access to this directory can modify this branch) on this structure?

One of the doubt I have is about `priv` and (the absence of) `priv_len`. I am not sure why `priv` has a different type `void *` than the public key in the kex; do we want the same here?

Other thing about the message and hashing: do we want to make anything explicit on that matter?

comment.body: I think your proposed signing API looks good, @dstebila. I might have further comments when I sit down to integrate a signature scheme, but it's a good starting point. Keeping it consistent with the KEX API makes sense.
